utterances: Do you think that this recording is also a way for you to give thanks for the successes you've had in the music industry?
I've always giving thanks.
And I tell the audience before every show, the first thing I say is don't judge me because I'm not coming home to gospel.
I've been gospel all my life.
See, in my shows, I always had two or three gospel songs in my secular shows.
And I was blessed with the secular stick to go out there and make money and do things for people because of my secular career, which is 45 years.
And there are a lot of people in certain places and certain areas and oh, she didn't do so well on her secular world so she's coming home to gospel.
Those people need to stop and think because I'm not coming home to anything.
I've been here.
I just don't believe in going to church because of what my minister did to me.
Everybody can sit back and point fingers.
And I say to you at the beginning of the show, don't judge me because you don't know me, and you don't know my hardships.
You don't know what I've been through in this business.
How concerned are you about how successful it may or may not be or is it something that you have done, really, to fulfill your own inner self?
Oh, that's such a good question.
I really hope this sells billions because all the proceeds go to cancer.
Because we have to find a cure, and if I can help…
(Singing) …somebody has to pass along.
Then my living shall not be in vain.
If it helps one person, I'm doing it for that reason.
And I'm Robert Siegel.
Many of us use Facebook, and we want to keep using Facebook.
And Facebook is a business.
So what exactly is the fix here?
Yeah.
Well, let's not get ahead of ourselves.
That's for coming weeks.
This week it's about the squid that light up.
Light up squid.
Light up squid on our Web site at sciencefriday.com.
Talking with Flora Lichtman, our producer for digital media.
Thank you, Flora.
Thanks, Ira.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
And I'm Madeleine Brand.
A diplomatic development today for Iraq.
It restored diplomatic relations with its neighbor Syria.
The two countries severed those relations 24 years ago.
Better relations between the two might help with the unrelenting violence in Iraq.
We're joined from Baghdad by one of the key players in the talks between Iraq and Syria.
That's Iraq's Foreign Minister Hoshyar Zebari.
Mr. Zebari, welcome to DAY TO DAY.
You're most welcome.
What can you tell us about this development?
Can Syria really be a true partner for helping to quell the violence in Iraq?

Well, we hope that Syria would be a partner, will cooperate with the Iraqi government on the security issue, that it will live up to its commitment and the responsibilities that it shoulder, and the - and numerous resolutions to help and assist stabilize Iraq.
This was the first visit by a senior Syrian official to Baghdad over the last three years.
This visit has been worked out very closely by the Iraqi government and the Syrian government for several months of negotiation, of contacts until it had happened.
Mr.
Zebari, you say you've been talking to the Syrians for months.
Did you tell the U.S.
government about this?
Because this government opposes talks with Syria.
No, this was an Iraqi government decision, in fact.
We have been talking with Iran, another of our neighbors, with Syria, with Turkey and Saudi Arabia.
That's why this is an Iraqi business, basically.
And we have been praising our friends from the American Embassy also about those ongoing discussions.
The U.S.
military said as recently as yesterday that up to 100 foreign fighters crossed the Syrian border into Iraq every month.
Do you agree with that figure?
And did you ask the Syrians to stop this?
And what did they say?
Well, this is not news in fact.
They're going on for quite some time.

And, yes, indeed, we have confronted the Syrian with all the intelligence, with all the information that my government or our security organization has at their disposal to help and assist and be positive.
But we were not expecting to resolve all the difficulties in our relations through one visit.
This is a process and needs to be followed up through some tactical teams to serious discussions.

So concerted efforts by both governments in order to engage Syria and constructively, there hasn't been any lack of willingness or desire by my government to reach out to Syria and to others to engage and help stabilize the situation.
Mr.
Zebari, Iraq's president, your president Jalal Talabani, is going to Iran this coming weekend for meetings with top officials there.
Is that correct?
In fact, President Talabani is responding to an outstanding invitation by the Iranian government.
It has been postponed several times, but it will take place soon.
This would be a bilateral visit.
There would be meeting with the key Iranian leaders to discuss the same issues that we have discussed with the Syrian visiting delegation.
So, you'll be talking with the Iranians about, about what?

Well, about everything, about their role, about the security issues, about their influence, about their assistance to the government, that this government needs to be stabilized, to stand on its feet, to be able to control violence, sectarian violence, terrorism, because the spillover is imminent if Iraq were to fail.
Iraq's Foreign Minister Hoshyar Zebari.
Mr. Zebari, thank you for speaking with us on Day to Day.
You're welcome.
Fabulous vacations live on in pictures - that perfect sunset, the view across the Grand Canyon, the postcards from the museum.
Disasters live on in family lore.
Chicago Tribune columnist Eric Zorn pointed out that the rainy boat trip, the sunstroke and the traffic jam evolve into stories that get told and retold long after the chigger bites have healed.
We want to hear today about your most memorable family vacation disaster and how you talk about it today.
Give us a call: 800-989-8255, email us talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation on our Web site.
That's at npr.org, click on TALK OF THE NATION.
Eric Zorn joins us now from Chicago.
Nice to have you with us.
Hi, Neal.
Thanks.
So tell us about your family trip to Seattle.
Well, we had a lovely trip to Seattle last week.
We went up to Mount Rainier, and we went up the Space Needle and saw the Pike Place Market and the Historic District and everything.
But the most memorable time we had was when we went to the Pacific Science Center there.
It was a rainy afternoon, like it is here in Chicago today.
And we ducked into the IMAX theater.
And we - they were only showing this one film called ""Animalopolis."" And the person who sold me the ticket said, you know, this is really for younger people.
And I said, well, you know, but it's IMAX.
How bad could it be?
Going to be pretty pictures, yeah.
It'll be pretty pictures.
And yeah, there were pretty pictures, but this thing was really geared at lik e 2-year-olds.
It was an extremely childish IMAX movie with a lot of nice wilderness pictures.
You know, I'm not saying it's a bad movie for 2-year-olds, but you got to remember for every 2-year-old in the audience is an adult who's got to sit through this thing.
And we started a big argument.
I ended up grabbing a chair, lashing it against the wall and leaving the room.
And I said, `Keep your script if you don't want to go there.'
Whether citizens will be buying from the state or growing their own is still being decided.
But two things are clear: Uruguay wants to try something radically different.
And no one here seems worried about what the U.S.
might think about it.
Drug official Julio Calzada.
(Through Translator) The reality now is that American hegemony is being questioned more and more, economically and culturally.
And that means new openings for certain debates.
For NPR News, I'm Annie Murphy in Montevideo.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

Chicago is having a bloody year.
Homicides there are up more than 50 percent over this time last year.
The city has long struggled with a gang problem, one of the worst in the country.
But NPR's David Schaper reports that this early surge in shootings has everyone puzzled, from crime experts to neighborhood activists.
DR. LARRY MITCHELL: This is where all the action starts.
Right about here.

Dr. Larry Mitchell is walking through the clicking automatic sliding entry door into the emergency room at Rosewood Community Hospital on Chicago's far south side on what could be a very busy Friday night.
